repnme.cdata!: Recovering from civil war in Rwanda

abstracts.cdata!:
In 1995, the Rwandan post-war government
            started liberalizing the trade and currency regimes and also
            key product markets. Following the massive return of more
            than a million refugees to Rwanda, the World Bank in June
            1997 approved a 50 million dollars economic reintegration
            and recovery interest-free credit to support the
            government's reform program and assist in the
            resettlement and reintegration of those returning to their
            homeland. The return of refugees to their communities during
            1996 and 1997 boosted agricultural production, which rose 14
            percent between 1996 and 1998. The reforms spurred a rapid
            recovery of the private and financial sectors. Real gross
            domestic product (GDP), which declined by 50 percent in
            1994, rebounded by 24 percent between 1996 and 1998.

In 1995, the Rwandan post-war government
            started liberalizing the trade and currency regimes and also
            key product markets. Following the massive return of more
            than a million refugees to Rwanda, the World Bank in June
            1997 approved a 50 million dollars economic reintegration

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            and the sustainability of the reform program supported by
            the project is likely. Overall performance of the World Bank
            is rated satisfactory: The Bank helped to sharpen the reform
            agenda through frank and patient dialogue with the
            Government, carefully nurtured the ownership of the reform
            program in the country by raising awareness among
            stakeholders of the need for reforms to address
            Rwanda's deep-seated econonomic and social problems.
            Borrower performance is also overall satisfactory. Lessons
            learned include the following: To be effective, the project
            design needs to be sensitive to the capacities of government
            and private entities in a post-conflict situation. It is
            important to be flexible and patient, and to regularly
            consult with other development partners as capacity is weak
            and operating conditions are subject to unexpected change.
            There are often widely divergent perception of the risks,
            which can be narrowed by dialogue between the parties.
            Second, regular supervision missions and strong monitoring
            by the Bank is esential when the Borrower's capacity is
            limited. Provision of capacity building is essential. In the
            case of Rwanda, the Bank overestimated the speed of
            processing legislation through the bureaucracy, the Cabinet,
            and the National Assembly. To avoid delays and undue
            pressure on the National Assembly, it is recommended that
            conditionality be linked only to presentation of the
            relevant laws to the National Assembly.

5084420.majtheme: Rural development,Financial and private sector development,Economic management,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Recovery Credit aims at
            consolidating the ongoing economic recovery and stability,
            reducing rural poverty, laying the foundation for private
            sector-led growth, and enhancing the prospects for national
            reconciliation by opening up economic opportunities to all
            Rwandese. The economic reform program will enable
            Rwanda's economy make the transition from state control
            to a market based orientation. This reforms will focus on:
            a) maintaining macroeconomic stability and improving public
            resource mobilization and management; b) developing
            market-oriented agriculture and reviving the rural economy;
            c) enhancing the role of women; d) establishing the
            institutional and legal framework conducive to private
            sector growth; and e) privatizing state enterprises,
            strengthening public administrative capacity, and improving
            service delivery. The program will bring benefits which
            include: a) the consolidation of the ongoing economic
            recovery; b) the increase in rural production and incomes;
            c) the creation of employment; and d) the improvement of
            public social and other key services.
